column8: Description
column14: Dictionary Entry Name

column8: The BAS_Business_Segment (Table 4) and the BAS_Business_Segment_Hierarchy (Table 6) have been designed to tabularize the portions of an organizational chart that is reflected in the business transactions as structural units, e.g. business unit, department, cost center and project. Instructions on how to implement the business segment structures (4.4.2 and 4.4.3) are detailed in Annex A.The fields within the BAS_Business_Segment (Table 4) are used to capture the individual organizational unit represented by each box on an organizational diagram.
column14: ADCS_ Business Segment. Details

column8: The code of each business segment.
column14: ADCS_ Business Segment. ID
column25: XBRL GL tracks hierarchy ID, hierarchy description, and hierarchy type, so it can track code "NA," description "N. America," and type "global area" using gl-cor:accountSubID, gl-cor:accountSubDescription, and gl-cor:accountSubType, respectively. Interrelations and hierarchies are captured by gl-cor:parentSubAccountType (What is the hierarchy type this unit rolls up to?).

column8: The name of the business segment.
column14: ADCS_ Business Segment. Business Segment. Name
column25: See above; an unlimited number of units and structures are permitted.

column8: The relative level of the segment with being the consolidated level and numbers increasing through lower levels of the organizational chart.
column14: ADCS_ Business Segment. Segment Reference Level. Code
column25: The relationships between higher-level hierarchies are captured once per Business Segment.

column8: Indicates the name of the organization type, for example, "Department" and "Cost Center".
column14: ADCS_ Business Segment. Organization Type. Name

column8: The fields in the BAS_Business_Segment_Hierarchy (Table 6) are used to capture the relationships between the individual organization units. The table assumes a one_to_one relationship and captures the data necessary to consolidate transactions occurring for child level organizational units into higher level organizational structures (for example, business unit to division).  Instructions on how to implement the business segment structures (see 4.4.2 and 4.4.3) are detailed in Annex A.
column14: ADCS_ Business Segment Hierarchy. Details

column8: The code of the parent business segment. Shall match the Business_Segment_Code in the BAS_Business_Segment table.
column14: ADCS_ Business Segment Hierarchy. Parent. ADCS_ Business Segment

column8: The code of the child business segment. Shall match the Business_Segment_Code in the BAS_Business_Segment table.
column14: ADCS_ Business Segment Hierarchy. Child. ADCS_ Business Segment

column8: The personnel information of the employee in an independent accounting unit is contained in Table 8.
column14: ADCS_ Employee. Details

column8: The unique identifier for an employee. Typically auto-generated by the system.
column14: ADCS_ Employee. ID

column8: The code of the employee. Each employee has only one code. If someone does part-time jobs in multiple departments, there will be more than one record with different Employee_ID in this table. And the part-time status will be reflected in Employee_Type_Code.
column14: ADCS_ Employee. Code

column8: The name of the employee.
column14: ADCS_ Employee. Name

column8: Indicate whether one employee is active or inactive. One employee may become inactive due to some reasons such as sabbatical.
column14: ADCS_ Employee. Inactive Flag. Indicator

column8: The code of the employee types. EXAMPLE Using 004 to represent an on-the-job employee, 005 to represent a retired employee, 006 to represent a deceased employee, and 007 to represent a part-time employee.
column14: ADCS_ Employee. Type Code

column8: The name of the employee type. EXAMPLE Employed, retired, probation and part-time.
column14: ADCS_ Employee. Type Name

column8: The code of department rosters. EXAMPLE The IT department is designated as code 0018. Shall match the Business_Segment_Code in the BAS_Business_Segment table.
column14: ADCS_ Employee. Department. ADCS_ Business Segment

column8: The title of the person in an accounting unit. EXAMPLE Accounting manager.
column14: ADCS_ Employee. Job Title. Name

column8: The highest academic degree acquired. EXAMPLE Doctor, Master.
column14: ADCS_ Employee. Academic Degree

column8: The employment date of the employee.
column14: ADCS_ Employee. Employment Date

column8: The termination date of the employee from which the labor contract was no longer valid, or the employee no longer works in this department.
column14: ADCS_ Employee. Termination Date

column8: The system user ID associated with the employee. hall match the User_ID in the BAS_User table.
column14: ADCS_ Employee. Associated. ADCS_ User

column8: The user information of accounting and/or ERP system is contained in Table 10.
column14: ADCS_ User. Details

column8: The unique identifier for the individuals entering transactions into the accounting and/or ERP system. Typically auto-generated by the system. This field is used to join information in this table to other tables based on the fields such as Created_User_ID, Last_Modified_User_ID, Approved_User_ID and Posted_User_ID, respectively.
column14: ADCS_ User. ID

column8: This indicates whether the status of the user is active or inactive. A user may become inactive due to retirement, dismissal or termination etc. EXAMPLE 1 is active and 0 is inactive.
column14: ADCS_ User. Active Status. Code

column8: The modified date of the user's activation or termination status.
column14: ADCS_ User. Status Modified Date

column8: The name of the user.
column14: ADCS_ User. User Name

column8: The title of the person in the system. EXAMPLE System manager.
column14: ADCS_ User. User Job Title. Name

column8: The code of department rosters of the use. EXAMPLE The department name is IT department and the code is 0018. Shall match the Business_Segment_Code in the BAS_Business_Segment table.
column14: ADCS_ User. Department. ADCS_ Business Segment

column8: Free form description of the individual's functional role or primary responsibility. EXAMPLE Responsibility related to managing the information of accounts payable in the system.
column14: ADCS_ User. User Role Responsibility

column8: Detailed descriptions of the customer type are contained in Table 12.
column14: ADCS_ Customer Type. Details

column8: The unique identifier for the customer type. Typically auto-generated by the system.
column14: ADCS_ Customer Type. ID

column8: The code of the customer type. EXAMPLE Using 004 to represent a Platinum customer, 005 to represent a Gold customer and 006 to represent a Silver customer. Customer_Type_Code and Customer_Type_Name are not necessarily related.
column14: ADCS_ Customer Type. Customer Type. Code

column8: The name of the type categorized by the customer attributes. EXAMPLE Platinum customer, Gold customer and Silver customer.
column14: ADCS_ Customer Type. Customer Type. Name

column8: The unique identifier for the parent customer type. Typically autogenerated by the system. Shall match the Customer_Type_ID in the BAS_Customer_Type table.
column14: ADCS_ Customer Type. Parent. ADCS_ Customer Type

column8: The essential and generic information of the customers is contained in Table 14.
column14: ADCS_ Customer. Details

column8: The unique identifier for the customer. Typically auto-generated by the system.
column14: ADCS_ Customer. ID

column8: The number of the customer. This number is generated either by manual input or by the system.
column14: ADCS_ Customer. Customer Account Number. Code

column8: The name of the customer.
column14: ADCS_ Customer. Customer Account. Name

column8: The abbreviation of the customer's name.
column14: ADCS_ Customer. Abbreviation

column8: The unique identifier for the parent customer. Shall match the Customer_Account_ID in the BAS_Customer table.
column14: ADCS_ Customer. Parent. ADCS_ Customer

column8: The unique identifier for the corresponding supplier in case that the customer is also a supplier. Shall match the Supplier_Account_ID in the BAS_Supplier table. Otherwise set NULL.

column8: The unique identifier for the customer type. Typically auto-generated by the system. Shall match the Customer_Type_ID in the BAS_Customer_Type table.

column8: The customer's tax identification number. This number is usually generated by tax regulator.
column14: ADCS_ Customer. Tax Identification Number. Code
ADCS_ Customer. Physical_ Address. ADCS_ Address
ADCS_ Customer. Billing_ Address. ADCS_ Address
ADCS_ Customer. Crresponding. ADCS_ Primary Contact

column8: The date that the customer was declared inactive. For example a customer may become inactive due to exceeding credit limit, legal restrictions, contract termination or bankruptcy etc.
column14: ADCS_ Customer. Inactive. Date

column8: The per invoice credit limit established for the customer.
column14: ADCS_ Customer. Transaction Credit Limit. Amount

column8: The credit limit for the customer's total outstanding balance.
column14: ADCS_ Customer. Total Credit Limit. Amount

column14: ADCS_ Customer. Terms Discount. Percentage

column8: The number of days from the invoice date the customer has to take advantage of discounted terms. Terms are represented as integers with no decimal places. EXAMPLE 10 days would be represented as 10.
column14: ADCS_ Customer. Terms Discount Days. Numeric

column8: The default number of days allowed to meet the obligation before an invoice becomes overdue.
column14: ADCS_ Customer. Terms Due Days. Numeric

column25: gl-cor:documentReference / Rather than using a data field, use XML's ID at the top level of the structure. You can use both XML IDs and IDREFs to create physical links between related documents.

column8: The code of the supplier type. EXAMPLE Using 004 to represent preferred suppliers, 005 to represent key suppliers, and 006 to represent common suppliers.
column14: ADCS_ Supplier Type. Code

column8: The name of the type categorized by the supplier attributes. EXAMPLE Preferred supplier, key supplier and common supplier.
column14: ADCS_ Supplier Type. Name

column8: The abbreviation of the supplier's name.
column14: ADCS_ Supplier. Abbreviation

column8: The unique identifier for the parent supplier. Typically auto-generated by the system. Shall match the Supplier_Account_ID in the BAS_Supplier table.

column8: The information about GL accounts, including name, description, type and hierarchy is contained in Table 20. When it is cross-referred by other table(s), consistency shall apply. For example, in this table, the value of GL_Account_Number is 101, the value of GL_Account_Name is cash, and the value of Balance_Debit_Or_Credit is D, if the value of GL_Account_Number in GL_Tial_Balance table is 101, then the Amount corresponding with cash account (101) must be debit.
column14: ADCS_ Chart Of Accounts. Details

column8: The GL account number.
column14: ADCS_ Chart Of Accounts. ID

column8: The name of the GL account.
column14: ADCS_ Chart Of Accounts. GL Account. Name

column8: The label or description associated with the GL_Account_Number.
column14: ADCS_ Chart Of Accounts. Description

column8: The financial statement caption represents a related group of accounts. EXAMPLE Cash and cash equivalents, accounts payable and cost of sales. The caption can be at the trial balance level.
column14: ADCS_ Chart Of Accounts. Caption

column8: The type of account. EXAMPLE Assets, liabilities, equity, revenues and expenses.
column14: ADCS_ Chart Of Accounts. Account Type. Code

column8: The subtype of the account. EXAMPLE Current assets are the subtype of assets.
column14: ADCS_ Chart Of Accounts. Accountount Subtype. Code

column8: The corresponding level for account number in the account hierarchy. EXAMPLE Using 1 to represent assets, and 2 to represent the account subtype current assets.
column14: ADCS_ Chart Of Accounts. Account Hierarchy. Numeric

column8: The number of the parent account in an account hierarchy. This is provided to allow more than the predefined levels of the hierarchy in the BAS_Chart_Of_Accounts table. When Parent_GL_Account_Number is the highest level, its value can be set to the default value; for example, set to NULL. Shall match the GL_Account_Number in BAS_Chart_Of_Accounts table.
column14: ADCS_ Chart Of Accounts. GL Account Number. ADCS_ Chart Of Accounts

column8: This field is used to indicate whether the natural balance of the account is a debit or credit balance by indicating "D" or "C", where assets and expenses have a natural balance of debit, and liabilities, equity and revenues have a natural balance of credit.
column14: ADCS_ Chart Of Accounts. Debit Or Credit. indicator

column8: This indicates whether the GL account is active or inactive. EXAMPLE 1 is active and 0 is inactive.
column14: ADCS_ Chart Of Accounts. Active Flag. Indicator
ADCS_ Chart Of Accounts. X. ADCS_ Business Segment

column8: The information related to accounting period including the corresponding fiscal year, the beginning and ending date is contained in Table 22. The table captures the time range within a specific reporting period and year, in which business transactions and entries are accumulated into financial statements and other reports.
column14: ADCS_ Accounting Period. Details

column8: The fiscal year in which the calendar date occurs. The year shall be shown in four digits as "YYYY", which is part of the extended format and the "YYYYMM-DD" in ISO 8601-1.
column14: ADCS_ Accounting Period. Fiscal Year. Code

column8: The accounting period in which the calendar date occurs. EXAMPLE W1_W53 for weekly periods, M1_M12 for monthly periods, Q1_Q4 for quarterly periods, and from any beginning date to any ending date.
column14: ADCS_ Accounting Period. Period. Code

column8: The calendar beginning date of the current accounting period.
column14: ADCS_ Accounting Period. Beginning. Date

column8: The calendar ending date of the current accounting period.
column14: ADCS_ Accounting Period. Ending. Date

column8: The information relevant to the GL journal entry type is contained in Table 24. For example, cash receipts, cash disbursements are contained.
column14: ADCS_ Journal Entry Type. Details

column8: The code of the journal entry type. EXAMPLE Using 004 to represent a cash receipt entry, 005 to represent a cash disbursement entry, and 006 to represent a non-cash entry.
column14: ADCS_ Journal Entry Type. ID
column25: gl-cor:documentReference / Rather than using a data field, use XML's ID at the top level of the structure. You can use both XML IDs and IDREFs to create physical links between related documents.

column8: The name of the journal entry type. This is usually categorized by business to satisfy an internal control need and/or to facilitate sorting and querying; for example, journal entries could be classified based on whether the transaction involves cash. In this case there may be cash receipt entry, cash disbursement entry, and non-cash entry of adjusting that is the recording of interest revenue earned and wages payable, estimation that is the recording depreciation, and bad-debt expenses, and/or correction that makes entries to counteract the effects of errors found in the general ledger.
column14: ADCS_ Journal Entry Type. JE Type. Name

column8: The abbreviation of the journal entry type.
column14: ADCS_ Journal Entry Type. Abbreviation

column8: This indicates whether the JE type is active or inactive. EXAMPLE 1 is active and 0 is inactive.
column14: ADCS_ Journal Entry Type. Active Flag. Indicator

column8: The information of bill type, for example, bank draft, commercial draft, promissory note and check are contained, is contained in Table 26. Bills are frequently used in the business cycle of sales and purchase, as evidence of debt, payment and/or settlement instrument.
column14: ADCS_ Bill Type. Details

column8: The code of the bill type. EXAMPLE Using 004 to represent bank draft, 005 to represent promissory note, and 006 to represent check.
column14: ADCS_ Bill Type. ID
column25: gl-cor:documentReference / Rather than using a data field, use XML's ID at the top level of the structure. You can use both XML IDs and IDREFs to create physical links between related documents.

column8: The name of the bill type. EXAMPLE Bank draft, commercial draft, promissory note and check.
column14: ADCS_ Bill Type. Bill Type Name

column8: This indicates whether the bill type is active or inactive. EXAMPLE 1 is active and 0 is inactive.
column14: ADCS_ Bill Type. Active Flag. Indicator

column8: The information on methods used to settle transactions is contained in Table 28. Businesses can adopt various methods to settle transactions and transfer money, especially in sales and purchase activities. Typical settlement methods include: cash settlements, issuing bills, using credit cards, bank remittances and bank collections.
column14: ADCS_ Settlement Method. Details

column8: The code of the settlement method. Various methods can be used to settle transactions and transfer money; for example, 001 for cash, 002 for bills, 003 for credit card, 004 for remittance, and 005 for bank collection.
column14: ADCS_ Settlement Method. ID

column8: The name of the settlement method. EXAMPLE Cash settlement, issuing bills, credit card, bank remittance and bank collection.
column14: ADCS_ Settlement Method. Settlement Method. Name

column8: This indicates whether the settlement method is active or inactive. EXAMPLE 1 is active and 0 is inactive.
column14: ADCS_ Settlement Method. Active Flag. Indicator

column8: The information of the currency is contained in Table 30.
column14: ADCS_ Currency. Details

column8: The code of the currency (ISO 4217).
column14: ADCS_ Currency. ID

column8: The name of the currency in the accounting and/or ERP system.
column14: ADCS_ Currency. Currency. Name

column8: The unit of recorded value which is a division of the respective unit of currency. Minor unit shows the decimal relationship between such unit and the currency itself (ISO 4217). Number 0 means that there is no minor unit for that currency, whereas number 1, 2, 3, etc. signify a ratio of 10:1, 100:1, 1 000:1, etc. respectively. EXAMPLE The US cent is a one hundredth part of the US dollar; the GB penny is a one hundredth part of the pound sterling. The minor unit number for both is 2.
column14: ADCS_ Currency. Minor Unit. Numeric

column8: This indicates whether Currency_Code is active or inactive. EXAMPLE 1 is active and 0 is inactive.
column14: ADCS_ Currency. Active Flag. Indicator

column8: The information of the measurement unit (UOM) used in the modules of general ledger, sales, purchase, inventory and PPE is contained in Table 32.
column14: ADCS_ Measurement Unit. Details

column8: The code of the measurement unit.
column14: ADCS_ Measurement Unit. ID

column8: The name of the measurement unit for measuring the quantity of the material, etc.
column14: ADCS_ Measurement Unit. UOM. Name

column8: The abbreviation of the measurement unit's name. EXAMPLE Kilogram is recorded as "kg" and square meter is recorded as "sq.m".
column14: ADCS_ Measurement Unit. Abbreviation

column8: This indicates whether the UOM_Code is active or inactive. EXAMPLE 1 is active and 0 is inactive.
column14: ADCS_ Measurement Unit. Active Flag. Indicator

column8: The details of the payment term, which is applied and referenced in the purchase and sales modules, are contained in Table 34. The payment term refers to the condition of a sale/purchase agreement and is related to how the customer will pay (type of credit instrument), and especially how much time is allowed for payment (credit period) and discount (cash discount and discount period).
column14: ADCS_ Payment Term. Details

column8: The code of the payment term. EXAMPLE Terms of 2/10, net 60 could be quoted. This means that customers have 60 days from the invoice date to pay the full amount. However, if payment is made within 10 days, a 2 percent cash discount can be taken.
column14: ADCS_ Payment Term. ID
column25: gl-cor:documentReference / Rather than using a data field, use XML's ID at the top level of the structure. You can use both XML IDs and IDREFs to create physical links between related documents.

column8: The full name of the payment term.
column14: ADCS_ Payment Term. Payment Term. Name

column8: The number of the lines according to the Payment_Term_Code value. This number is generated either by manual input or by the system.
column14: ADCS_ Payment Term. Line_Number. Code
column25: gl-cor:documentReference / Rather than using a data field, use XML's ID at the top level of the structure. You can use both XML IDs and IDREFs to create physical links between related documents.

column8: The detailed description of the payment term's line. EXAMPLE Payment due date, discount days, and discount percentage.
column14: ADCS_ Payment Term. Description

column8: This indicates whether the payment term is active or inactive. EXAMPLE 1 is active and 0 is inactive.
column14: ADCS_ Payment Term. Active Flag. Indicator

column8: The detailed information related to the project, for example, construction project, government or business-funded research project are contained, is contained in Table 36. Projects are commonly administered separately and could be subject to being audit in accordance with regulatory and/or managerial requirements. The audit of a project is a thorough examination of the management, execution, methodology, procedures, records, budgets, expenditures, and the degree of completion. It is referenced in several modules including the GL, AR, AP and Inventory.
column14: ADCS_ Project. Details

column8: The unique identifier for the project. Typically auto-generated by the system.
column14: ADCS_ Project. ID
column25: gl-cor:documentReference / Rather than using a data field, use XML's ID at the top level of the structure. You can use both XML IDs and IDREFs to create physical links between related documents.

column8: The ending date of the project.

column8: The detailed information on tax types used by the business is contained in Table 42. Tables in AR, Sales, AP and Purchase modules contain 4 tax types respectively, which can meet requirement of most cases of the business. Tax types could be tax in country level, in state level, in county level or in local level, or tax related to a transaction, for example, sale tax, value added tax or tariff.
column14: ADCS_ Tax Type. Details

column8: A code used to refer to this tax type, used as a key or cross-reference in files. EXAMPLE Using 004 to represent the income tax, 005 to represent the tariff, and 006 to represent the value added tax.

column25: gl-cor:documentReference / Rather than using a data field, use XML's ID at the top level of the structure. You can use both XML IDs and IDREFs to create physical links between related documents.

column14: ADCS_ Tax Type. Description

column14: ADCS_ Tax Type. Tax. Percentage

column8: An account segment is a customized file item, which includes the information of the customized account segments that are not fixed account segments and no other table contains their description information, for example region type. This table is used together with the BAS_Customized_ACC_Value.
column14: ADCS_ Customized Account Segment. Details

column8: The code of customized account segment which audit data needs to be used; this does not include the fixed account segment having been identified; for example, unlike customer, budget information is not included in the Base module as an individual table, therefore budget can be identified as a customized account segment.
column14: ADCS_ Customized Account Segment. ID
column25: gl-cor:documentReference / Rather than using a data field, use XML's ID at the top level of the structure. You can use both XML IDs and IDREFs to create physical links between related documents.

column8: The customized account segment name which audit data needs to be used; for example, budget records planned revenue and expenditure.
column14: ADCS_ Customized Account Segment. Customized Account Segment Name

column8: The customized account segment description which audit data needs to be used; for example, budget can be described as the annual plan of aggregated fiscal revenue and expenditure for a state, which is verified and approved through legal procedures.
column14: ADCS_ Customized Account Segment. Description

column8: The encoding rules of the value of a customized account segment. If the encoding rule has a hierarchy feature, each level is separated by "-"; for example, budget (with 1-digit code, like 1) can be subdivided into financial budget (with 2-digit code, like 01) and construction budget (with 2-digit code, like 05), with the financial budget containing budgeted revenue (with 2-digit code, like 03) and budgeted expenditure (with 2-digit code, like 04), which are the thirdlevel segments. In this case, Customized_ACC_Encoding_Rule is 1-2-2.
column14: ADCS_ Customized Account Segment. Encoding Rule. Code

column8: Whether the table value has a hierarchy feature or not. EXAMPLE 1 means yes and 0 means no.
column14: ADCS_ Customized Account Segment. Hierarchy Flag. Indicator

column8: This indicates whether the Customized_ACC_Segment_Code is active or inactive. EXAMPLE 1 is active and 0 is inactive.
column14: ADCS_ Customized Account Segment. Active Flag. Indicator

column8: The information from the customized account segment value is contained in Table 46.
column14: ADCS_ Customized Account Value. Details

column8: The code of the customized account segment value. If the Customized_ACC_Encoding_Rule is 1-2-2, the corresponding budgetfinancial budget-budgeted expenditure is 10104.
column14: ADCS_ Customized Account Value. ID
column25: gl-cor:documentReference / Rather than using a data field, use XML's ID at the top level of the structure. You can use both XML IDs and IDREFs to create physical links between related documents.

column8: This field is associated with the BAS_Customized_ACC_Segment table. Shall match the Customized_ACC_Segment_Code in the BAS_Customized_ACC_Segment table.
column14: ADCS_ Customized Account Value. Associated. ADCS_ Customized Account Segment

column8: The name of the account segment value of each file. EXAMPLE budget-financial budgetbudgeted expenditure.

column8: The detailed description of the account segment value.
column14: ADCS_ Customized Account Value. Description

column8: The level of the current value in the file structure. EXAMPLE 1 means the highest.

column8: The industry and software version information is contained in Table 48. This table contains information related to the profile of the data being collected. For instance, when we extract the financial data of 2016 from an auditee using SAP XXX ERP System in 2017.1.16, we should have a record with the Profile_Name "XXX_2016", Fiscal_Year "2016", Developer_Name "SAP", Software_Name "SAP_S/4", Software_Version "2.0", Functional_Currency "CNY, Standard_Version "ISO 21378", Extracted_Date "2017-01-16".

This number is generated either by manual input or by the system.

column8: The code and name for account segment, as well as the GL_Account_Number to which the account segment is related are contained in Table 56. The account segment provides additional information for particular GL_Accounts; for example, the accounts receivable contains the information regarding supplier, customer, employee, and project. Such information would be treated as an account segment below A/R, thus resulting in a lengthy account structure. In light of this, the account segment structure is defined as a set to record related information, efficiently avoiding the case that account names and numbers are extended to be too long and too complex. Account segment is more flexible to capture the complicated information. Some of the most frequently used account segments, for example, project, employee and bank account, have been defined as fixed fields in tables, such as GL_Details. These segments are called fixed account segments in the document. Fixed account segments and other customized account segments are covered in this table. More details are presented in Annex B.
column14: ADCS_ General Ledger Account Segment. Details

column8: The GL account number. This number is generated either by manual input or by the system. Shall match the GL_Account_Number used in the BAS_Chart_Of_Accounts table.

column8: The number of the Account_Segment. Case 1 If the value of this field is 0, the record is used to explain a fixed account segment that is distinguished by Account_Segment_Name of the record. Case 2 If the value of this field is 5, the record is used to explain the No.5 field of Account_Segment_X, named Account_Segment_5 in the tables, such as GL_Details. This number is generated either by manual input or by the system.
column14: ADCS_ General Ledger Account Segment. ID
column25: gl-cor:documentReference / Rather than using a data field, use XML's ID at the top level of the structure. You can use both XML IDs and IDREFs to create physical links between related documents.

column8: The name of the Account_Segment. Case 1 If the value of Account_Segment_Number of the record is 0, the field contains the name of a fixed account segment, such as Account_Segment_Employee. Case 2 If the value of Account_Segment_Number of the record is 5, the field value should be the name of a customized account segment, like welfare expenditure.
column14: ADCS_ General Ledger Account Segment. Account Segment. Name

column8: The table corresponding to account segment. Case 1 If the value of Account_Segment_Number of the record is 0, the field contains the table name corresponding to the fixed account segment, such as BAS_Employee for Account_Segment_Employee. Case 2 If the value of Account_Segment_Number is larger than 0, and no other table besides BAS_Customized_ACC_Segment contains the basic information of the customized account segment, the field value should be BAS_Customized_ACC_Segment. Case 3 If the value of Account_Segment_Number is larger than 0, and there is a table contains the basic information of the customized account segment, the field value should be the table's name, such as BAS_Customer.

column8: The cumulative total and balance of accounts in each accounting period, facilitating the calculation of beginning, ending balance, duration amounts and quantity, thus reflecting information and changes in GL more intuitively are contained in Table 58. In this table, the quantity can serve different regulatory and managerial purposes. For example, subledgers of inventory and PPE may not be covered in some auditees’ systems. In this case, we can record the cumulative total and balance of quantity of inventory or PPE in this table. This is a well-established practice in some countries, like France and China. Countries can choose to use GL_Trial_Balance or GL_Accounts_Period_Balance or both, depending on their customary practice, regulatory and managerial requirements. This table is level 2.

column14: ADCS_ Local Tax. Tax Debit GL Account Number. ADCS_ Chart Of Accounts
column25: XBRL GL does not have fields explicitly associating GL accounts to tax, although it does permit specification of accounts as tax accounts (gl-cor:accountPurposeCode); it associates tax detail in the gl-cor:taxes structure with specific accounts by including them within the same gl-cor:entryDetail if the gl-cor:amount is the same, or within the same gl-cor:entryHeader if amounts differ. As with the previous GL lines, the account numbers would be mapped to gl-cor:accountMainID.

column8: The GL account number on which the credit side of the Tax4 transaction has been posted. Shall match the GL_Account_Number in the BAS_Chart_Of_Accounts table.
column14: ADCS_ Local Tax. Tax Credit GL Account Number. ADCS_ Chart Of Accounts
ADCS_ Transaction Tax. Details

column8: The code of Tax1 type. Shall match the Tax_Type_Code in the BAS_Tax_Type table.
column14: ADCS_ Transaction Tax. Tax Type. ADCS_ Tax Type
column25: gl-cor:taxCode (Note that XBRL GL permits an unlimited number of tax codes and amounts with the gl-cor:taxes structure.)

column8: The amount of Tax1 included in the transaction. Recorded in transac currency.
column14: ADCS_ Transaction Tax. Tax. ADCS_ Transaction Currency Amount

column8: The name of the tax type. EXAMPLE Income tax, Tariff and Value added tax.
column14: ADCS_ Tax Type. Tax. Name

column8: The code of the regulator for this tax. Shall match the Regulator_Code in the BAS_Tax_Regulatory table.
column14: ADCS_ Tax Type. Regulator. ADCS_ Tax Regulatory

column8: The description of the tax type.
column14: ADCS_ Tax Type. Description

column8: The description of the tax code, subdivision of the tax type. EXAMPLE Lower percentage applicable for common goods.
column14: ADCS_ Tax Type. Description

column8: Default percentage for this combination of tax type and tax code. Can as of the Extracted_Date from Profile table.
column14: ADCS_ Tax Type. Tax. Percentage

column25: XBRL GL does not have fields explicitly associating GL accounts to tax, although it does permit specification of accounts as tax accounts (gl-cor:accountPurposeCode); it associates tax detail in the gl-cor:taxes structure with specific accounts by including them within the same gl-cor:entryDetail if the gl-cor:amount is the same, or within the same gl-cor:entryHeader if amounts differ. As with the previous GL lines, the account numbers would be mapped to gl-cor:accountMainID.

column8: The GL account number on which the credit side of the Tax1 transaction has been posted. Shall match the GL_Account_Number in the BAS_Chart_Of_Accounts table.
